lines.text: [Lawrence has just extinguished a match between his thumb and forefinger. William Potter surreptitiously attempts the same]
Ooh! It damn well 'urts!
Certainly it hurts.
What's the trick then?
The trick, William Potter, is not minding that it hurts.
No Arab loves the desert. We love water and green trees. There is nothing in the desert and no man needs nothing.

I killed two people. One was... yesterday? He was just a boy and I led him into quicksand. The other was... well, before Aqaba. I had to execute him with my pistol, and there was something about it that I didn't like.
That's to be expected.
No, something else.
Well, then let it be a lesson.
No... something else.
What then?
I enjoyed it.
Truly, for some men nothing is written unless THEY write it.
Have you no fear, English?
My fear is my concern.
Gasim's time has come, Lawrence. It is written.
Nothing is written.
You will not be at Aqaba, English! Go back, blasphemer... but you will not be at Aqaba!
I shall be at Aqaba. That, IS written.
[pointing to forehead]
In here.
There may be honor among thieves, but there's none in politicians.
What is it, Major Lawrence, that attracts you personally to the desert?
It's clean.
It is Auda of the Howitat who speaks.
It is Ali of the Harith who answers.
Harith! Ali, does your father still steal?
No. Does Auda take me for one of his own bastards?
No, there is no resemblance. Alas, you resemble your father.
Auda flatters me.
You're easily flattered. I knew your father well.
Did you know your own?
So long as the Arabs fight tribe against tribe, so long will they be a little people, a silly people - greedy, barbarous, and cruel, as you are.
I am Auda abu Tayi! Does Auda serve?
NO!
Does Auda abu Tayi serve?
NO!

[to Lawrence]
I carry twenty-three great wounds, all got in battle. Seventy-five men have I killed with my own hands in battle. I scatter, I burn my enemies' tents. I take away their flocks and herds. The Turks pay me a golden treasure, yet I am poor! Because *I* am a river to my people!
My friends, we have been foolish. Auda will not come to Aqaba. Not for money...
No.
...for Feisal...
No!
...nor to drive away the Turks. He will come... because it is his pleasure.
[pause]
Thy mother mated with a scorpion.
I say, Lawrence. You are a clown!
Ah, well, we can't all be lion tamers.
If we've been telling lies, you've been telling half-lies. A man who tells lies, like me, merely hides the truth. But a man who tells half-lies has forgotten where he put it.

[talking of Britain]
Is that a desert country?
a fat country. Fat people.
You are not fat?
No. I'm different.
With Major Lawrence, mercy is a passion. With me, it is merely good manners. You may judge which motive is the more reliable.

[as Lawrence sets out across the desert with Daoud and Faraj]
You will cross Sinai?
Moses did!
And you will take the children?
Moses did!
Moses was a prophet and beloved of God!
What is your name?
My name is for my friends. None of my friends is a murderer!

There's nothing further here for a warrior. We drive bargains. Old men's work. Young men make wars, and the virtues of war are the virtues of young men. Courage and hope for the future. Then old men make the peace. And the vices of peace are the vices of old men. Mistrust and caution. It must be so.
Bedouins and gods, and you're neither. Take it from me, for ordinary men, it's a burning, fiery furnace.
No, Dryden, it's going to be fun.
It is recognized that you have a funny sense of fun.
You answered without saying anything. That's politics.
I can't make out whether you're bloody bad-mannered or just half-witted.
I have the same problem, sir.
[asked by reporter if he knew Lawrence]
Yes, it was my privilege to know him and to make him known to the world. He was a poet, a scholar and a mighty warrior.
[after reporter leaves]
He was also the most shameless exhibitionist since Barnum & Bailey.
Look, sir, we can't just do nothing.
Why not? It's usually best.
Are you badly hurt?
I'm not hurt at all. Didn't you know? They can only kill me with a golden bullet.

My lord, I think... I think your book is right. 'The desert is an ocean in which no oar is dipped' and on this ocean the Bedu go where they please and strike where they please. This is the way the Bedu have always fought. You're famed throughout the world for fighting in this way and this is the way you should fight now!
I do not understand this. Your father's name is Chapman...
Ali, he didn't marry my mother.
I see.
I'm sorry.
It seems to me that you are free to choose your own name, then.
Michael George Hartley, this is a nasty, dark little room.
That's right.
We are not happy in it.
It's better than a nasty, dark little trench.
Then you're an ignoble fellow.
That's right.
Never saw a man killed with a sword before.

[contemptuously]
Why don't you take a picture?
Wish I had.
It's my manner, sir.
Your manner?
Yes. It looks insubordinate, but it isn't really.

Which is why my father made this war upon the Turks. My father, Mr Lawrence, not the English. But my father is old and I... I long for the vanished gardens of Cordoba. However, before the gardens must come the fighting.
You, I suspect, are chief architect of this compromise. What do you think?
Me, your Highness? On the whole, I wish I'd stayed in Tunbridge Wells.
We do not work this thing for Feisal.
No? For the English, then?
For the Arabs.
The Arabs? The Howitat, Ajili, Rala, Beni Saha; these I know, I have even heard of the Harif, but the Arabs? What tribe is that?
No prisoners! No prisoners!

My friend Lawrence, if I may call him that. "My friend Lawrence". How many men will claim the right to use that phrase? How proudly! He longs for the greenness of his native land. He pines for the Gothic cottages of Surrey, is it not? Already in imagination, he catches trout and engages in all the activities of the English gentleman.
That's me you're describing, sir, not Colonel Lawrence.
What are you looking for?
Some way to announce myself.
Be patient with him, God.
You acted without orders, you know.
Shouldn't officers use their initiative at all times?
Not really. It's awfully dangerous.
I believe your name will be a household word when you'll have to go to the War Museum to find who Allenby was. You're the most extraordinary man I've ever met!
Leave me alone!
What?
Leave me alone!
Well, that's a feeble thing to say.
I know I'm not ordinary.
That's not what I'm saying...
All right! I'm extraordinary! What of it?
When Lawrence finds what he's looking for, he will go home. When you find what you are looking for, you will go home.
I will not.
Then you are a fool. Be thankful that when God gave you a face, he gave you a fool's face.

[leafing through Lawrence's dossier]
Undisciplined... unpunctual... untidy. Knowledge of music... knowledge of literature... knowledge of... knowledge of... you're an interesting man there's no doubt about it.
Here you may drink...
[Lawrence nods and takes out his canteen to drink water]
One cup.
[pointing the tincup]

[Lawrence pours in some water]
You do not drink?
No.
[Tafas shakes his head like saying no]
I'll drink when you do.
I am *Bedu*.
[Lawrence pours back the water in the tincup to canteen]
Ow, you rotten man... here, let me take your rotten bloody picture... for the rotten bloody newspapers.

There is the railway. And that is the desert. From here until we reach the other side, no water but what we carry with us. For the camels, no water at all. If the camels die, we die. And in twenty days they will start to die.
There's no time to waste, then, is there?
I thought I was a hard man, sir.
You are merely a general. I must be a king.
[Arabs are looting a train after blowing it up]
It is their payment, Colonel.
Payment?
Truly, are not British soldiers paid?
They don't go home when they've been paid!
They are not free to!

[on the Arab Revolt]
It's a storm in a tea cup, Mr. Dryden - a sideshow. If you want my own opinion, this whole theater of operations is a sideshow! The real war's not being fought against the Turks, but the Germans. And not here, but on the Western front in the trenches! Your Bedouin Army - or whatever it calls itself - would be a sideshow OF a sideshow!
Big things have small beginnings, sir.
Does the Arab Bureau want a "big thing" in Arabia? If we get them to rise against the Turks, does the Bureau think they'll sit down quietly under us when this war's over?
The Arab Bureau thinks the job of the moment, sir, is to win the war.
Don't tell me my duty, Mr. Dryden!
Does it surprise you, Mr Bentley? Surely, you know the Arabs are a barbarous people. Barbarous and cruel. Who but they! Who but they!
Well. It seems we're to have a British waterworks with an Arab flag on it. Do you think it was worth it?
Not my business. Thank God I'm a soldier.
Yes, sir. So you keep saying.

Well, General, I will leave you. Major Lawrence doubtless has reports to make upon my people and their weakness, and the need to keep them weak in the British interest... and the French interest too, of course. We must not forget the French now...

[indignantly]
I've told you, sir, no such treaty exists.
Yes, General, you have lied most bravely, but not convincingly. I know this treaty does exist.
Treaty, sir?
He does it better than you, General. But then, of course, he is almost an Arab.
I have been stationed in Dara for three and a half years. If I were posted to the dark side of the moon I could not be more isolated. You don't have the slightest idea what I'm talking about, do you?
No, effendi.
Do you? No. That would be too... lucky.

[after Lawrence enters with a dirty Bedouin]
This is a bar for British officers!
That's all right. We're not particular.

A thousand Arabs means a thousand knives, delivered anywhere day or night. It means a thousand camels. That means a thousand packs of high explosives and a thousand crack rifles. We can cross Arabia while Johnny Turk is still turning round, and smash his railways. And while he's mending them, I'll smash them somewhere else. In thirteen weeks, I can have Arabia in chaos.

[to Bentley, on a meeting between Lawrence and Allenby]
Well, I'll tell you. It's a little clash of temperament that's going on in there. Inevitably, one of them's half-mad - and the other, wholly unscrupulous.
[first lines]
He was the most extraordinary man I ever knew.
Did you know him well?
I knew him.
Well nil nisi bonum. But did he really deserve a place here?

[on his interest in Lawrence and the Arab Revolt]
I'm looking for a hero.
Indeed, you do not seem a romantic man.

Oh, no! But certain influential men back home believe the time has come for America to lend her weight to the patriotic struggle against Germany... and Turkey. Now, I've been sent to find material that makes this war seem more...
Enjoyable?
Oh, hardly THAT, sir. But to show it in its more... adventurous aspects.
You are looking for a figure that will draw your country towards war?
All right, yes.
Lawrence is your man.
What ails the Englishman?
The one he killed is the one he brought out of the Nafud.
It was written then. Better to have left him there.
[Lawrence and Ali watch as British cannons fire in the distance]
God help the men that lie under that.
They are Turks.
God help them.
I'm to "assess the situation".
Hmph! Well that won't be too difficult. The situation's bloody awful.
The English have a great hunger for desolate places. I fear they hunger for Arabia.
Then you must deny it to them.
You are an Englishman. Are you not loyal to England?
To England and to other things.
To England and Arabia both? And is that possible? I think you are another of these desert-loving English.
"We've taken Aqaba" the generals would laugh.
I see. In Cairo you will put off these funny clothes. You'll wear trousers and tell stories of our quaintness and barbarity and then they will believe you.
You're an ignorant man.
Do you know General Allenby?
Watch out for Allenby. He's a slim customer.
Excuse me?
A clever man.
Slim customer. It's very good... I'll certainly watch out for him. you're being very sympathetic Mr. Bentley.
But you know, Lieutenant, in the Arab city of Cordoba were two miles of public lighting in the streets when London was a village?
Yes, you were great.
Nine centuries ago.
Time to be great again, my lord.
I pray that I may never see the desert again. Hear me, God.
I'm promoting you Major.
I don't think that's a very good idea.
I cannot fiddle but I can make a great state of a small city.

No, they're still there, but they've no boots. Prisoners, sir. We took them prisoners; the entire garrison. No, that's not true. We killed some; too many really. I'll manage it better next time. There's been a lot of killing, one way or another. Cross my heart and hope to die, it's all perfectly true.
I'm an ordinary man. You might've told me that, Dryden.
The best of them won't come for money; they'll come for me.
The Law says the man must die... If he dies, would that content the Howitat?
Yes.
Sherif Ali. If none of lord Auda's men harms any of yours, will that content the Harith?
Yes.
Then I will execute the Law. I have no tribe and no one is offended.
I've got orders to obey, thank God. Not like that poor devil. He's riding the whirlwind.
Let's hope we're not.
And I must do it because the Turks have European guns. But I fear to do it. Upon my soul I do. The English have a great hunger for desolate places. I fear they hunger for Arabia.
[regarding the bullet wound on Lawrence's arm]
Where did you get this wound?
That is old, effendi.
No, it is recent. You are a deserter. But from which army? Not that it matters at all. A man can't always be in uniform.

[his last words, to Ali]
Being an Arab will be thornier than you suppose, Harith!
Is Major Lawrence in there? Is he in trouble?
I would suspect so. We all have troubles. Life is a vale of troubles.
You are an Englishman. Are you not loyal to England?
To England, and to other things.
Aurens! Can you pass for an Arab in an Arab town?
If one of you will lend me some dirty clothes.
[last lines]
Well, sir, going home!
Mm?
[realizes that he has been addressed]
Home, sir!
"Goodbye Dolly, I must leave you... "]
What about your Arab friends? What about them?
I have no Arab friends. I don't want Arab friends !
What in Hell do you want, Lawrence?
I told you! I just want my ration of common humanity.
Lawrence!
[Lawrence turns away from Allenby to face Dryden]
Nothing. Sorry I interrupted, Sir.

[subdued]
Quite all right. Thank you, Mr Dryden. Look, why don't we, er... There's blood on your back. Do you want a Doctor ?
Where are they now?
Anywhere within 300 miles of Medina. They're Hashemite Bedouins. They can cross 60 miles of desert in a day.
Oh,thanks Dryden. This is going to be fun.
Beduins and gods, and you're neither. Take it from me. For ordinary men, it's a burning fiery furnace.
No,Dryden. It's going to be fun.
It is recognised that you have a funny sense of fun.

[Ali shots Tafas dead while riding his camel. He stops his camel and jumps down to see Tafas' body]
He is dead.
yes... why?
this is my well.
[mentioning the well Lawrence and Tafas just used for resting]
I have drunk from it.
You are welcome.
He was my friend.
That?
[mentioning Tafas]
Yes, that.

[Ali walks towards peter and grabs tafas' gun lying on the sand]
This pistol yours?
No, his.

[Ali places the pistol to his waist and walks towards the well]
His?
[mentioning the tincup near the well]
Mine.
hen i will use it.
[pulls some water out of well]
... your friend... was a Hazimi of the Beni Salem.
I know.

[Ali salutes Lawrence and drinks his water]
I am Ali ibn el Kharish.
I have heard of you.
So... What was a Hazimi doing here?
He was taking me to help Prince Feisal.
You've been sent from Cairo?
Yes.
I have been in Cairo for my schooling. I can both read and write... my Lord Feisal already has an Englishman.
Yes.
What is your name?
My name is for my friend.
[Ali walks away]
None of my friends is a murderer.
You are angry, English.
[Ali climbs his camel]
He was nothing. The well is everything... The Hazimi may not drink at our wells. He knew that... Salaam.
To be great again, it seems that we need the english... or...
Or?
What no man can provide, Mr. Lawrence. We need a miracle.
Thine mother mated with a scorpion.
What I owe you is beyond evaluation.
Do you think I'm just anybody, Ali? Do you?
Damn it, Lawrence! Who do you take your orders from?

[the British army staff is having a field briefing]
Very well, gentlemen. The cavalry's gone through Mazril and Deraa. Very good, by the way, very good indeed. Now your turn.
Well, sir, if the enemy's retreating in any kind of order - which we'd better assume...
Certainly.
...Then they can't be further than this Mallud place. In which case I can have them within range by... 0900 hours tomorrow?
Splendid! Phillip.
Well, these
[referring to British soldiers marching in the background]
are the last of the infantry supports coming up now, sir. But Mallud... could have the fusilliers there by... Wednesday, sir?
That'll do for now. The guns are what matter! Any questions?
This Arab army on the right, sir - what's it consist of?
Irregular cavalry, sir. About two thousand.
Where are they now?
Can only know that by being with them, sir.
Then get with them, Harry! I want to know.
Yes, sir.
Pound them, Charley -
[strikes blackboard with his fist]
POUND THEM!
I fight like Clausewitz, then you fight like Saxe!
We should do very well, then, shouldn't we?
I may as well tell you, it's my considered opinion and that of my staff that any time spent on the Bedouin will be time wasted.They're a nation of sheep-stealers.
They did attack Medina.
And the Turks made mincemeat of them.
We don't know that.

We know that they didn't take it. A storm in a teacup, a sideshow. If you want my own opinion, this whole theatre of operations is a sideshow. The real war's being fought against Germans, not Turks. And not here, but on the Western front in the trenches. Your Bedouin Army, or whatever it calls itself would be a sideshow of a sideshow.
Big things have small beginnings, sir.
Sherif Ali!. So long as the Arabs fight tribe against tribe, so long will they be a little people, a silly people. Greedy, barbarous and cruel, as you are.
Come. I will take you to Feisal.
I do not want your company, sherif.
Wadi Safra is another day from here. You will not find it, and not finding it you will die.
I will find it with this.
[showing the compass]

[Ali suddenly takes the compass with his stick]
Good army compass. How if I take it?
Then you would be a thief.
Have you no fear, English?
My fear is my concern.
Truly.
[Ali gives back the compass to Lawrence]
God be with you English.
[And he rides away]
I've been waiting for you.
Did you know I was coming?
I knew someone was coming. I mean Feisal told me.
How did he know?
Not much happens within 50 miles of Feisal that Feisal doesn't know. I'll give him that... no escort?
My guide was killed at the Masturah well.
Turks?
No, an Arab.
Bloody savages.
[They both ride away]

[Auda starts the attack on Aqaba with these words]
Make God your agent!... Aqaba!
Lord, can we not rest?
[riding on the camel along with Lawrence and Daud]
I told you, no rest till they know that I have Aqaba... Have you two slept in beds? Farraj? Daud? With sheets?
[they nod like saying no]
Tomorrow the finest sheets in the finest room, in the finest hotel in Cairo. I promise.
Then it shall be so, Lord.
